Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) will continue its collaboration in providing to early- and mid-career scientists and engineers experiential professional development and public service fellowships via the AAAS Science and Technology Fellowship Program. Consistent with the immersion model adopted by AAAS, Fellows at NSF will be selected annually through a competitive process and placed in organizations throughout the Foundation. Fellows will work with NSF staff on a broad range of activities in order to gain insight into how national science and technology policy goals are translated into and reflected by NSF's mission and strategic goals and how and by whom national science and technology policy is driven, shaped and prioritized. NSF fellowship assignments are designed to: educate and expose Fellows to NSF programmatic planning, development and oversight activities in all fields of fundamental research via hands-on engagement; utilize the Fellows' expertise on projects that apprise NSF officials in areas of mutual interest to the Fellow and the host organization; and provide developmental opportunities to inform future career decisions. The program includes an orientation on executive branch and congressional operations, as well as a year-long suite of knowledge- and skill-building seminars involving science, technology and public policy within the federal as well as NSF contexts.

In the long-term, the AAAS Fellowship program seeks to build leadership capacity for a strong national science and engineering enterprise. Upon completion of the Fellowship, Fellows will have gained: a broader understanding and increased insights about the development and execution of federal-level science, technology, engineering and mathematics policies and initiatives as well as how policy and science intersect; enhanced skills in communicating science to support policy development; and a greater capacity to serve more effectively in future leadership roles in diverse environments, including public and policy arenas, academia and the private sector. The ultimate outcome of the Fellowship program experience -- policy savvy science and engineer leaders who understand government and policymaking and are well-trained to develop and execute solutions to address the nation's challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Under this award, the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) placed one fellow at NSF through its Science & technology Policy Fellowships program (STPF), over the period of September 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019. The broad objective is to build S&T leadership to support evidence-based policy and practice. AAAS provided policies and guideline; conducted recruitment, selection and placement; programmatic management; administration of fellowship support; and implementation of professional development programs for the fellow at NSF.  Created in 1973, STPF has extensive experience operating federal policy opportunities for scientists and engineers and places fellows each year in all three branches of government. AAAS administers the 1 to 2 year fellowship assignments, which augments NSF's scientific and technical expertise. Fellows are selected through a rigorous merit review process. They are supported with a professional development program, including orientation, seminars, skill-building workshops, careet enhancement sessions, and gatherings to foster resource sharing and collaboration. Fellows learn through immersion in NSF host offices the process for analyzing, developing, and implementing policies and programs that affect the national science agenda. they engage in a range of research programs, communication and education initiatives across NSF's focus areas. Fellows contribute expertise, analytical talent, time, energy and external perspectives and connections to NSF's core purpose to promote achievement and progress in science and engineering and enhance the potential for research and education to contribute to the nation.

 

Intellectual Merit: The S&T Policy Fellowships are an opportunity for professional development and public service, as a part of the AAAS mandate to "advance science and serve society." The aim is to foster evidence-based policy and practice by engaging scientists and engineers from a broad range of disciplines, backgrounds and career stages to directly contribute knowledge and analytical skills for well-informed federal policy actions; to learn first-hand about policymaking and implementation at the federal level; and to build leadership capacity for a strong S&T enterprise. The fellowship experience cultivates critical policy leadership skills in a cohort of doctoral level scientist and engineers, aligning with recommendations from the recent National Academies report Graduate STEM Education for the 21st Century. Annual reports of fellows' activities highlight a wide range of projects and contributions to NSF initiatives, and a gain of knowledge, experience and networks that enable fellows to move into positions of greater influence.

 

Broader Impacts: This project develops a diverse network of alumni places across all sectors who are prepared to execute, communicate, and teach a vision of policy informed by science and technology. Since 1973, more than 3,000 scientists and engineers have been through the STPF program, with 312 of those having served at NSF. All carry with them an understanding of U.S. government programs and initiatives; the many factors affecting policy; and the critical importance of research, applied science, and outreach that address social, economic, and environmental challenges, support public policy, and contribute to the well-being of the nation and citizens around the world.
